bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The notebooks written by Bokari Kanneh date to the 1950s. They were written in the Kikakui script of the Mende language. The creation of Kikakui is commonly credited to Kisimi Kamara, a tailor from the village of Vaama, Sierra Leone, in the 1920's. According to Konrad Tuchscherer in his article "African Script and Scripture: The History of the Kikakui (Mende) Writing System for Bible Translations", African Languages and Cultures , vol. 8 #2, regional oral tradition maintains that Mohammed Turay, Kamara's uncle and teacher, developed the original 42 characters of the syllabary. Kamara added approximately 150 additional characters and popularized the use of the written language. Kanneh was a Muslim goldsmith of Mende and Maninka ancestry who lived in Nyandeyema, Nongowa Chiefdom, Kenema District, Sierra Leone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection of eight notebooks and additional loose pages, comprising about 250 leaves of notes, includes a manual for writing Mende numbers, a sample of the syllabary as used for teaching the script, a diary of activities, and financial accounts.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Dr. Konrad Tuchscherer discovered this collection of notebooks while doing research in the region and acquired them directly from Kanneh in March of 1994. He donated them to the Yale Art Gallery in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These documents include four pages of the Mende alphabet, or syllabary, written out in the set style used for teaching the script. There is also a partial letter to Kanneh and what appears to be a story or history of some kind.
